right thank you very much good afternoon everybody my name is Dave Starck and I am a
principal platform engineer with direct supply in Milwaukee Wisconsin today I'm
going to talk you through how we're using file gateway as a target for sequel server backups now direct supply
is a company that serves the long-term care industry so think nursing homes everything from assisted living up to
the most intense acute care everything in between and we serve that industry in
three ways that we refer to as build equip and run so our build story is that
we have an interior design architecture and construction organization that can
handle projects of any scale from a cosmetic facelift to the complete design and delivery of a fully outfitted
nursing facility our equip story is really the roots of our building our
business we were founded as a maintenance equipment company and quickly expanded into medical products
and durable goods for the long-term care industry today we publish a 2,000 page
catalog every year and operate a large e-commerce portal that long-term care industry facilities can use to purchase
all the products they need to equip and serve their patients there's two pieces
to our run story the first is an equipment life cycle group that we refer to as tells they provide services and
support around the equipment that we sell and we can also help facilities locate ancillary services like electricians plumbers gardeners things
like that so they are a service organization serving the long-term care industry we also operate a large
purchase and procurement portal that we refer to as DSS I so we connect facilities or corporations of facilities
with all of their preferred vendors on the back end and lay our our own home-grown toolset on top of that
purchasing process so that they can understand and a better track and manage their spend and forecast upcoming needs now we
were founded about 34 years ago and very early on in our company's history we founded our 1st IT department and the
goal of that department was to develop solutions using technology that gave us an advantage in serving our customers so
we were doing things very early on in our history like customer relationship management software before you could
just go out to Salesforce and set that up yourself we were doing data analytics
and data reporting before those were off-the-shelf products we were very early adopters of e-commerce practices
and selling over the web all of this has been homegrown in a largely Windows environment now today our physical
infrastructure in our own data center is about 800 VMs a hundred physical servers supporting those VMs and all of our data
including backups and dr copies takes up about 1.2 petabytes of storage
now just for context we put our first storage array into our data center in
2003 it was a whopping 4 terabytes and we were only about 30 percent occupied
when we put it in so our data has exploded over the last decade and a half and continues to grow now all of this IT
all of this software all of this infrastructure supports our 1,200 partners about 300 of which work
remotely through a VDI environment that we also maintain and support and together they serve our thousands of
customers every day now a few years ago we had a very familiar story that
probably most of you have gone through we had a lot of infrastructure that was coming up for end-of-life and life cycle
or end of support start of extended support and that's a very high dollar amount position to be in we also were
running everything on Windows and we wanted to introduce more open source into our environment where it made sense to and we wanted to start automating
more of our processes and adopt more DevOps like behaviors in our environment
so we decided to use of open-source software and we built our own private
cloud running on essentially an open source hypervisor with a very large amount of customization on top of it
running on commodity hardware now our goal is a business is to improve the
lives of America's seniors by making it easier for their health care to be provided for managing that
infrastructure was not in our core competencies there's a lot of work that goes into maintaining and off-the-shelf
infrastructure let alone an infrastructure that we've grown ourselves so we made the decision to
pivot away from our private cloud project and we partnered up with rellis cloud to figure out how do we move our
on-campus workloads out to AWS so they came in and they helped us train up our
first five engineers on our cloud team and we set about the business of figuring out our environment and our
infrastructure so that we could plan out our move to AWS we started with our
landing zone things like our V pcs and subnets setting up some of our basic
security policies and then we as a cloud team figured out our standards for how
we're going to operate in the cloud and this is this is important so we adopted things like everything that makes sense
to automate should be automated everything should be stored as infrastructure as code so we wanted to
be able to change track every single thing that we turned you know turned on
or off changed in our environment we wanted to have that tractus code third on that list was we wanted to make our
design agile so that we could adopt new technologies and new features as they
became available and we didn't commit ourselves to a very hard line specific architecture that can't evolve with the
cloud and then last on that list we wanted to make repeatable patterns so
that the right way to do something is the easiest way to do something so we spent a lot of time developing the
Service Catalog and various automations that other teams can consume to reproduce reliable infrastructure
patterns very easily now all of that in play allowed us to grow our team from five members to 25
members at the beginning of this year so we brought in 20 new partners when I say partners I mean employees so
we brought in 20 new employees onto our cloud team got them very quickly trained up and our first migration was our
secret reporting environment so there's several terabytes of data running in Microsoft sequel that we were going to
build in ec2 and we need to get all of our partners working together to make
that migration a success now the nice thing about our secret reporting environment is that while it is business
critical the blast radius is relatively small so if anything were to go bump in the night it doesn't affect our customers being
able to get their products and goods delivered it just means that we have to get it fixed very quickly now that
that's done we are shifting gears into looking at our e-commerce environment which is going to be an even bigger migration for us so with that background
one of the things that we had to solve for in our migration to the cloud was how we're going to protect sequel so on
campus we have sequel doing a log backup every 15 minutes to an AZ environment
every night it does a differential or a full backup to that same nas environment and then our backup software comes along
picks up that data and writes it out to a data domain a purpose-built disk based
backup appliance now both the nas and the data domain are replicated to our dr
site so if we had a failure we've got all the equipment and all of the data that we need to be able to recover to
within 15 minutes of the crash and have that system online within about two hours well we didn't want to have all
that infrastructure out in the cloud so we knew we had to think differently about how we're going to approach backups in the cloud so the first piece
of our story here is that you've probably heard the cattle versus pets conversation when in regards to cloud
architecture the real high level on that is that pets are things you invite into your home and you take care of you love
them they've got a bed in front of the fireplace you've given them a name they're very special and you're gonna do everything you can to keep your pet
happy and healthy cattle on the other hand Roman herds and if one of them tips over you just go to the auction and
bring a new one back in to the herd so we wanted to operate in a way that we identified our data as the
pets our sequel data is the special sauce the compute and the sequel instance running in front of it if we're
doing that as infrastructure is code then rather than firefight and troubleshoot why an instance might not
be behaving properly we can just relaunch the instance from scratch and get a brand-new fresh instance
automatically so by doing that it allowed us to rethink the role of deduplication in our environment we
backup 800 copies of C colon backslash Windows every single night and our data
domain does a great job of deduping all of that data so that we're really only storing one copy of that windows
directory in the cloud are switched to managing our actual compute nodes as
cattle allowed us to eliminate needing to build a D dupe solution in AWS again
we're protecting the data the operating systems are disposable and reproducible
so the third thing we wanted to do is accelerate our backup and restore the
data that we were storing on the data domains required a backup team member to restore the data back to the NAS device
before our D bees could start fixing whatever was wrong with our sequel data we wanted to move all of that backup
data closer to the application so that the D bees could work effectively without
having to involve other teams and create other escalations the fourth thing is we
wanted to make sure we maintained application consistency with our backups so you might be thinking well why don't
you just use snapshots of your volumes well that's great but we need to snapshot several data and log volumes consistently and we didn't want to lose
any data that was in flight so letting sequel write its backups out in a crash consistent manner was a much better
approach for us all right so when we got
into AWS our desired state like I said we wanted to eliminate the backup application from the data flow
altogether so no more Conville no more data domain we wanted to still be able to produce a log backup every 15 minutes
and be able to recover a sequel environment within about two hours and then we wanted to make sure that because
now we're able to replicate to a secondary physical data center that we some means of replicating that data to
another location in our case that was a separate region and we're actually working on building a separate account
that will replicate that data into so if anything happens to our primary account we have a completely separate account
with all of our data in it that we can use to recover the business so file
gateway became kind of the cornerstone of our architecture here in the cloud so within our file gateway each sequel
instance has its own prefix or in the prefix in the bucket or a file path through the Gateway when that sequel
server starts up it runs a mount command that attaches it directly to its path in
that gateway all of its backups are stored in that path so on every single
sequel server that we're running it appears as a local mapped drive for all of their backups now again this is the
same file gateway architecture slide that we saw earlier the Gateway has a cache volume so when we write our
backups they're writing to that cache volume and then the Gateway is copying that data to s3 the most recent relevant
data is remaining in that cache until we need to free up space in the cache so if we have to do a restore right after a
log backup well it's going to be pulling that right from the cache now like I
said one of our early cloud principles that we adopted was we wanted to automate everything and at the time we
were doing this a few months ago there was no cloud formation or terraform that would allow us to automate the gateways
so we kind of reverse engineered the process that goes on when you launch this from the console and we have a
simple bash script that uses terraform to stand up the infrastructure so if you're not familiar with terraform it's
an infrastructure is code language that you can use to deploy your infrastructure so that stands up this an
ec2 instance running the storage gateway ami it configures and creates the EBS
cache volume the security group with the correct ports open so we can communicate
to the Gateway over NFS it creates our Amazon s3 bucket and it creates the i.m
policy that allows our gateway to manage contents within that bucket when all
that is stood up our script makes sure that the resources are online and then it goes through the same process that you through in the console to activate the
Gateway configure the cache volume create the share and then our last step
is that we tagged all of these resources so that if we need to assemble the mount
path and mount string as code we can pull all of the necessary components right from the tags on the Gateway
alright so outcomes of this architecture we were able to maintain our 15-minute recovery point objective because we left
sequel scheduling those backups every 15 minutes the recovery time objective of
two hours is still in play but the great thing is that we have eliminated CommVault from the entire process so
that RTO goal hits for any restore that we would do going back through our entire backup archive not just the
backup we produced last night a few enhancements we want to boost the i/o
capabilities of our cache volumes so I'm going to go from gp2 to an i/o optimized volume on that and we're likely gonna
increase the size of our gateway ec2 instance from an m4 extra-large to a larger instance right now we've got
several sequel instances backing up to this and we want to keep one single namespace in the environment so rather
than having additional gateways out there we want to just grow the size and scale up a bit the last thing we're
gonna do is where we run all of our jobs at the same time every morning and it creates a very spiky workload and we'd
rather be a little more consistent and intentional about how those jobs run against one another so we'll probably be
taking on some scheduling work as well now our relationship with Gateway doesn't stop there we've also launched a
file gateway with SMB and are in the process of migrating a 30 terabytes I've
out to that gateway so we film every major campus event all of our company
picnics all of our you know if we have guest lecturers come in all of our quarterly shareholder meetings all of
that video footage is the the filmed history of our company and we don't want to give that up so the archive is a
perfect use we have 10 people that need to modify the archive in a single active directory group and we have it readable
to the entire company so the security model fits exactly with the POSIX based permissions that the
Mb stack in the file gateway is going to give us so we're in the process user
acceptance testing has gone fantastic and we're in the process of figuring out the next steps to get that data all the
way out into a file gateway after that like I mentioned we produce a 2,000 page
catalog every year and that takes a lot of photographs and a lot of creative content and we have that content also
living on premises in a large Nazz environment so there are some tighter integrations between that data and some
other third-party products that help populate some of our website content so we're working on those integrations and
we'll likely be moving that data out next to get that off of our our Nass filer as well and then after that we
have a large corporate file server that we need to redesign and it holds all of our user-generated content so we're
looking at ways that we can break that up and prepare that to move out to AWS as well all right
